content.description:
Climbing line starts to the right of the first bolt between a rock ledge and the main face. Devious slab climbing off the ground is protected by a high first bolt (Stick clip this). The high bolt keeps a leader from striking the rock ledge behind in a fall and was explicitly intended to be stick clipped.Â 

 Snag a great rest after clipping the second bolt and then move through a series of interesting, but well protected boulder problems, including a second crux before clipping the anchors.

 Starting off of a stem from the rock ledge eases the grade, and skips the lower half of the first boulder problem, but wont make the route any less fun.
content.protection:
Stick clip the very high first bolt. 4 more bolts to to chains with permanent lower-offs.

 All of the hardware is stainless steel except for the painted plated steel lower offs.

 The route can be set up on TR by doing a painful (locust thorn) 5th class scramble to the top of the climb from behind the wall to the left as you make the approach.
content.location:
This route is up around on a semi hidden rock face left of the main climbs. You cannot see it from the main climbing area.

 To locate it, walk left around the base of the cliff face from the main climbs for approximately 150 meters until the slope eases up, then double back along the lower face of the cliff until you can scamble up into the alcove that contains this climb.

 If you do the approach correctly it should be pretty easy with no 5th class moves.

content.description: Shares the first two/three bolts with South Fork Forty, then follows the natural line up and to the right to a bolted anchor.This line was originally climbed by Todd Skinner in the late 80's. The first 3 bolts are buttonheads of that time period, and caution should be used when leading on them.The bolted anchor was installed for this line and the wider easier crack to the right, known as "South Fork Forty"Updated route info provided by Richard Malone
content.protection: Bolts, Standard Rack. Can be set up on top-rope from a scramble to the left of the climbs
content.location: The rightmost line on the wall.

content.description:
Wow, what a gem! Climb through thoughtful but easier climbing to the third bolt, then move left onto the face for the fourth. Snag a good rest after the slight run out to the 5th, because it is primo slab climbing from here out. 5 more bolts gets you to the anchors, the last one is bizarrely close to the anchors.

 Excellent rock and just plain fun movement, especially the cruxy second half.

 Apparently named because the first ascensionist took his wife there on their first date and had her as the belay. (Thanks Warren for the FA info)
content.protection: 10 bolts, bolted anchor. Can be set up on top-rope from a scramble to the left of the climbs.
content.location: Middle of the three lines. The right most bolted line

content.description: Steeper start than First Date, with similar climbing up top. Work through the thuggy roof section before gaining a good rest in the middle. Then face down the techy, thin slab, to the anchors.
content.protection: Bolts. Bolted anchor. Can be set up on top-rope from a scramble to the left of the climbs.
content.location: Leftmost bolted line on the main wall.

content.description:
A true gem, this small wall has a few high quality sport routes and one trad line that can all be set up on top rope as well. The climbing is right next to several pools on the Rio Bonito, so this is a nice summer option when you are looking for a low key climbing outing combined with a dip in the river.

 There are also several boulders in the area that have potential for a few quality problems on good granite.
